utterances: Eric, welcome back.
Hey.
So the plot of this show has Patrick Stewart playing a self-destructive British newscaster named Walter Blunt who comes to L.A.
to host a cable talk show.
So this is like a fish out of water type thing.
Yeah, and what's good about this is that Patrick Stewart kind of throws himself into every scene he's in.
He gamely does whatever they ask him to do, no matter how outlandish.
And this show has a pedigree.
Seth McFarlane is the executive producer.
You know him from ""Family Guy"" and the movie ""Ted."" Oscar nominee actress Jacki Weaver is in it.
And it's really an interesting situation.
We have this guy who drinks too much, he does drugs, he has these public scandals and he has to talk about it all with his psychologist, who's played by Richard Lewis.
So here we've got a clip of the two of them together.
Let's check it out.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""BLUNT TALK"")
(As Walter Blunt) I put my career in jeopardy, I'm a lousy to middling father and I've hurt every woman I've ever been with.
(As Dr. Weiss) And what do you think would lessen your negative feelings about yourself?
(As Walter Blunt) Well, a woman.
(As Dr. Weiss) So what's holding you back from meeting a woman?
(As Walter Blunt) My track record.
All my relationships end in pain.
(As Dr. Weiss) Did that stop Elizabeth Taylor?
Yeah, we got an Elizabeth Taylor joke here.
OK.
I mean, it's kind of a weird choice for a show that's supposed to be a contemporary comedy about celebrity culture in the news business.
So that gives you a hint of some of the problems they have with it.
Oh, problems.
OK, Eric, it sounds like you're not exactly a big fan of this show.
What's going on?
Well, this show is ultimately a collection of a bunch of scattered jokes that don't really add up to, like, a larger idea.

I mean, you want this program to say some insightful stuff about the news business or the nature of celebrity or the absurdity of modern life, but you're mostly following around this self-centered, eccentric, self-destructive, cable TV guy who seems sort of vaguely modeled after Piers Morgan, the former CNN host.
So in an odd way, it's kind of less than the sum of its parts.
All right, Eric, but Starz is trying to compete in a very, very crowded marketplace right now, right?
I mean, how does it do that?
Well, you're right.
The marketplace is crowded.
I mean, this year, we're going to have something like 400 TV series, right?

So, in an environment like that, Starz - this channel that asked people to pay an extra fee to access what they do - they really have to deliver exceptional programming, and not too many of Starz's shows have been that great.
Now this channel, they've been around since 1994.
They've got sister channels like Encore and MoviePlex, something like 30 million subscribers.

And you may remember some shows that they've had like a version of ""Spartacus."" They have an urban drama called ""Power,"" and they have this romantic drama about a time traveling World War II nurse called ""Outlander."" But even though ""Power"" and ""Outlander"" have connected with strong fan bases, they still don't have that visibility of shows on rivals like HBO and Showtime.
OK, so it sounds like basically they need a hit.
Why aren't they getting there?
Well, to put it another way, they need a hit show that defines the channel's brand for the world, especially the audience.
They've had these shows that are good, but they just don't land in the zeitgeist and talk about issues that are at the center of pop culture and how we talk about life.

They've got a show called ""Power,"" for example, that's a great urban drama, but it's overshadowed by Fox's drama, ""Empire,"" because ""Power"" doesn't really say a lot about race or urban life in the way that ""Empire"" does.
HBO had hits like ""Sex And The City,"" and now they have ""Game Of Thrones"" that defines a channel for audiences.
Showtime has ""The Affair."" Starz needs its version of that kind of a hit.

They've got some interesting programs coming up, including a drama about ballet called ""Flesh And Bone"" from a writer who worked on ""Breaking Bad,"" and they've got a series inspired by the ""Evil Dead"" movies called ""Ash Vs. Evil Dead."" But so far, series like ""Blunt Talk,"" they're just not there yet.
Death may be too strong a word, but the measure is stuck in the Senate.
Many lawmakers wanted to use that vote to bypass President Obama.
He has put off approving the pipeline that would bring oil southward from Canada.
Majority Leader Harry Reid said he would allow a vote on Keystone only if the Senate approved an energy efficiency bill first.
That bill failed.
And as NPR's Ailsa Chang reports, that may be just fine with Senator Reid.

Here was the dilemma facing Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid: Some Senate Democrats - especially vulnerable ones running in conservative states this year - want to support the Keystone XL oil pipeline.
This is the 1,200-mile pipeline stretching from western Canada all the way to the Gulf Coast that has yet to be finished.
Most Democrats don't want a vote on Keystone.
So, how does Reid find a way out?
Avoid a Senate vote on the pipeline and blame Republicans for it.
Look at how Republican obstruction is bringing the Senate to its knees, again and again and again.
And now even on this bill - a bipartisan bill.
The bill Reid is actually talking about here is one that would help increase energy efficiency in federal buildings and private homes.
For days, Reid has said, only after that bill passes would he then allow a stand-alone vote on Keystone.
He then blocked the other side from introducing amendments to change the bill, which made many Republicans - like John McCain of Arizona - vow they'd, in turn, block the energy efficiency bill.
The dictator won't allow us to have any amendments.
I mean, it is just unprecedented.
I've been around here a long, long time.
And that's the procedural dance that let Senate Democrats avert a Keystone vote this time around.
This is a tough issue for Democrats, because it divides the Democratic Party, and it sets the Democratic Party and Congress against the president.

Frances Lee of the University of Maryland points out the president would have likely vetoed any bill this year giving the green light to build the Keystone, and most Democrats don't want that drama with the White House months before the election.
But where does that leave red state Democrats facing tough races this year, like Mary Landrieu of Louisiana?
They could have had a vote on Keystone.
They can't take yes for an answer.
She's already blaming Republicans for messing up the Keystone vote.
She can tell her constituents at least she tried and hope that's good enough.
Ailsa Chang, NPR News, the Capitol.

We'll bring your voices together in harmony - or harmony of sorts.
And next week, we'll play the whole thing on the air.
Go to our website, NPR.org, or the MORNING EDITION Facebook page for the full instructions.

Well, we'll try, anyway So when you record yourself, try to follow along with our pitch and tempo, which will be fast.

As ready as I'll ever be, Linda.
Here we go.

Plenty of people have asked why it wasn't easier to come up with a better website than healthcare.gov.
Not that building a website is so simple, but companies like Amazon or eBay have been able to make them straightforward and easy to use.
So three young programmers in San Francisco decided to take up the challenge.
The result is a new website: HealthSherpa.com.
It helps overcome at last some of the upfront problems people are experiencing with the government site.
